title: Snakes survive starvation by employing supply- and demand-side economic strategies
keyAssumptions: Traditional metabolic theory assumes fixed metabolic rates; Starvation survival primarily about energy storage; Limited focus on dynamic metabolic regulation
citation: McCue, M. D. (2007). Snakes survive starvation by employing supply-and demand-side economic strategies. Zoology, 110(4), 318-327.
notes: Revolutionary paper demonstrating snakes can depress metabolic rate by 72% and employ dual supply/demand strategies. Studied Python regius, Elaphe obsoleta, Crotalus atrox over 168 days.

title: Characterization of the gila monster (Heloderma suspectum suspectum) venom proteome
authors: Kristian W. Sanggaard, Thomas F. Dyrlund, Line R. Thomsen, Tania A. Nielsen, Lars Brøndum, Tobias Wang, Ida B. Thøgersen, Jan J. Enghild
keyAssumptions: Helodermatid venom composition relatively simple; Focus on known peptide toxins; Bioactive peptides activated intracellularly
citation: Sanggaard, K. W., Dyrlund, T. F., Thomsen, L. R., Nielsen, T. A., Brøndum, L., Wang, T., ... & Enghild, J. J. (2015). Characterization of the gila monster (Heloderma suspectum suspectum) venom proteome. Journal of proteomics, 117, 1-11.
notes: First comprehensive proteome analysis identifying 39 proteins in Gila monster venom, including 19 previously unknown. Revealed post-secretion activation mechanism for exendins via neuroendocrine convertase.

title: Exendin-4 from Heloderma suspectum venom: From discovery to its latest application as type II diabetes combatant
authors: Michelle Khai Khun Yap, Nurhamimah Misuan
keyAssumptions: Synthetic drugs superior to natural compounds; Venom compounds primarily toxic; Short-acting incretin mimetics sufficient
citation: Yap, M. K. K., & Misuan, N. (2019). Exendin‐4 from Heloderma suspectum venom: From discovery to its latest application as type II diabetes combatant. Basic & clinical pharmacology & toxicology, 124(5), 513-527.
notes: Comprehensive review of exendin-4 discovery and development. 53% homology with GLP-1 but superior potency and DPP-IV resistance. Led to FDA approval of exenatide as first GLP-1 receptor agonist.

title: Release of exendin-4 is controlled by mechanical action in Gila monsters, Heloderma suspectum
authors: Carolyn M. Christel, Dale F. DeNardo
journal: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part A
keyAssumptions: Venom compounds only released during defensive biting; Exendin-4 serves purely predatory function; Hormone release from salivary glands unusual in reptiles
citation: Christel, C. M., & DeNardo, D. F. (2006). Release of exendin-4 is controlled by mechanical action in Gila monsters, Heloderma suspectum. Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part A: Molecular & Integrative Physiology, 143(1), 85-88.
notes: First evidence that exendin-4 release is mechanically controlled and may serve endocrine function in fuel homeostasis. Represents first example of salivary gland hormone secretion in reptiles.

title: Exendin-4 decelerates food intake, weight gain, and fat deposition in Zucker rats
authors: Malgorzata Szayna, Maire E. Doyle, Jennifer A. Betkey, Harold W. Holloway, Richard G.S. Spencer, Nigel H. Greig, Josephine M. Egan
keyAssumptions: Diabetes drugs should focus primarily on glucose control; Weight management requires separate interventions; Appetite suppression distinct from glucose regulation
citation: Szayna, M., Doyle, M. E., Betkey, J. A., Holloway, H. W., Spencer, R. G. S., Greig, N. H., & Egan, J. M. (2000). Exendin-4 decelerates food intake, weight gain, and fat deposition in Zucker rats. Endocrinology, 141(6), 1936-1941.
notes: Landmark study demonstrating dual benefits of exendin-4: glucose control and significant appetite suppression/weight loss. 14-day study in Zucker fatty rats showing immediate food intake reduction and sustained weight loss.

title: A model of optimal digestive strategy in infrequently-feeding snakes
keyAssumptions: Infrequently-feeding snakes benefit only from large prey; Gut downregulation not quantitatively modeled; Size determines optimal prey choice
citation: Ruxton, G. D. (2025). A model of optimal digestive strategy in infrequently-feeding snakes. Evolutionary Ecology, 39, 37-56.
notes: Mathematical model challenging long-held assumptions. Demonstrates that infrequently-feeding snakes of all sizes benefit from small prey consumption when practicing gut downregulation. Identifies gut downregulation as critical adaptation for food scarcity.
